This action is brought on behalf of the United States to enforce Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended, 42 U.S.C. § 2000e, et seq. (“Title VII”).

extracted.value: Enforcement of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964

evidence.text: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, Plaintiff, v. CITY OF DURHAM, NORTH CAROLINA, Defendant.

extracted.value: Plaintiffs: Individual, described as United States of America

evidence.text: No consolidation references in any document; case caption and filings indicate standalone matter

Upon consideration of the Joint Motion for Provisional Approval and Entry of Consent Decree filed by Plaintiff United States of America and Defendant City of Durham, North Carolina, and subject to final decision based on any objections, the Court finds that the terms of the proposed Consent Decree are fair, adequate, reasonable,

extracted.value: Order (01/15/25) granted Joint Motion for Provisional Approval of Consent Decree, finding terms fair, adequate, and reasonable, and directing scheduling of Fairness Hearing.

evidence.text: Case voluntarily dismissed (02/25/25) before settlement terms were incorporated into court order; no settlement dates exist
2024-10-07 | Joint MOTION for Provisional Approval and Entry of Consent Decree by United States.
CONSENT DECREE
No settlement enforcement disputes; case dismissed before settlement implementation

Since 2015, African-American applicants passed the written examination at a lower rate than white applicants. The difference between the pass rates of African-American and white applicants is statistically significant at more than 3 units of standard deviation when aggregating the years since 2015.

extracted.value: Durham's written examination (CEB) for Firefighter positions resulted in statistically significant lower pass rates for African-American applicants compared to white applicants since 2015, with differences exceeding 3 standard deviations.

evidence.text: 2024-10-07 | COMPLAINT against CITY OF DURHAM, NORTH CAROLINA filed by UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
Case Reassigned to JUDGE THOMAS D. SCHROEDER.
Minute Entry for proceedings held before JUDGE THOMAS D. SCHROEDER in WS-2
Case dismissed before Consent Decree was entered as final order; no decree obligations were ordered by the court
This Decree constitutes the entire agreement of the Parties, and supersedes all prior agreements, representations, negotiations, and undertakings not set forth or incorporated herein.

The Court shall retain jurisdiction over this Decree for the purpose of resolving any disputes or entering any orders that may be appropriate to implement the Decree until the obligations set forth in Paragraph 136 have been met.
No monitor appointed; no monitor reports referenced in any document
No monitor appointed or referenced in any document; Consent Decree contains no monitoring provisions

evidence.source_document: Joint Motion for Provisional Approval and Entry of Consent Decree
evidence.text: Plaintiff United States of America and Defendant City of Durham, North Carolina respectfully move the Court to (1) provisionally approve and enter the attached Consent Decree resolving this litigation; (2) to schedule a Fairness Hearing on the Terms of the Consent Decree for a date no earlier than 130 days after provisionally approving and entering the Decree; and (3) to stay all deadlines pending the Court’s determination of whether to enter the Decree as a final order at or after the Fairness Hearing on the Terms of the Consent Decree.

extracted.value: Joint Motion for Provisional Approval and Entry of Consent Decree (filed 10/07/24) requested court approval to enter Consent Decree, schedule Fairness Hearing 130+ days after approval, and stay deadlines pending Fairness Hearing.

evidence.text: Plaintiff United States of America hereby dismisses the above-captioned case pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 41(a)(1). The United States has determined not to proceed further in this matter.

extracted.value: Notice of Voluntary Dismissal (filed 02/25/25) dismissed the case under Fed. R. Civ. P. 41(a)(1) as the United States determined not to proceed further.

evidence.text: No related cases identified in any document; case code references (e.g., U.S. v. Cobb County) appear only in amicus briefs, not as related matters for this case

a. refrain from using written tests to screen and select applicants for DFD entry-level firefighter positions where such uses result in a disparate impact on African Americans, are not job related for the position in question and consistent with business necessity, and/or do not otherwise meet the requirements of Section 703(k) of Title VII, 42 U.S.C. § 2000e-2(k);

extracted.value: Plaintiff: Refrain from using written tests to screen and select applicants for DFD entry-level firefighter positions where such uses result in a disparate impact on African Americans, are not job related for the position in question and consistent with business necessity, and/or do not otherwise meet the requirements of Section 703(k) of Title VII, 42 U.S.C. § 2000e-2(k)

evidence.text: b. provide make whole remedial relief to all persons who have suffered individual loss as a result of the discrimination alleged in this Complaint;

extracted.value: Plaintiff: Provide make whole remedial relief to all persons who have suffered individual loss as a result of the discrimination alleged in this Complaint

evidence.text: c. adopt other appropriate nondiscriminatory measures to correct the present effects of its discriminatory policies and practices, including the use of entry-level firefighter selection procedures that comply with Title VII.

extracted.value: Plaintiff: Adopt other appropriate nondiscriminatory measures to correct the present effects of its discriminatory policies and practices, including the use of entry-level firefighter selection procedures that comply with Title VII

evidence.text: The City of Durham, North Carolina, shall take all necessary steps to ensure that the written examination for the DFD Firefighter position is non-discriminatory and that any practices causing disparate impact on African-American applicants are eliminated.

extracted.value: Durham must ensure written examination for DFD Firefighter positions is non-discriminatory and eliminate practices causing disparate impact on African-American applicants.
